verses.text: Then I turned to see all the oppression that is done under the sun. Behold, the tears of the oppressed, and they have no comforter. On the side of their oppressors there is power, and they have no comforter.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes human suffering and the lack of earthly consolation. The repetition of 'no comforter' hints at the need for divine intervention, prefiguring Christ as the true comforter (John 14:16).

verses.text: And I thought the dead who are already dead more fortunate than the living who are still alive.
verses.comment: The author sees death as a relief from suffering, echoing Job’s despair (Job 3). This view highlights the fallen state of creation and indirectly points towards the hope of resurrection offered in Christ (1 Thess. 4:13-14).

verses.text: But better than both is he who has not yet existed, who has not seen the evil that is done under the sun.
verses.comment: This verse intensifies the bleakness, showing the burden of witnessing evil. Theologically, this foreshadows the doctrine of original sin and the world’s need for redemption.

verses.text: Then I saw that all toil and all skill in work come from a man's rivalry with his neighbor. This also is vanity and striving after wind.
verses.comment: Human effort is often motivated by envy, reflecting the brokenness of fallen relationships. This calls the reader to a higher love, echoing the New Testament call to charity and humility (James 3:16).

verses.text: The fool folds his hands and consumes his own flesh.
verses.comment: Idleness leads to self-destruction. This is a literal reflection on sloth, but spiritually it calls for an active pursuit of virtue and grace.

verses.text: Better is a handful of quietness than two handfuls of toil and a chasing after wind.
verses.comment: Contentment with little is better than restless striving, echoing wisdom literature. Appeals to the virtue of moderation, a key theme in spiritual life.

verses.text: Again, I saw vanity under the sun:
verses.comment: The recurring theme of vanity frames the entire narrative, emphasizing the need for meaning beyond worldly pursuits.

verses.text: There is one who is alone, without companion, he has neither son nor brother, yet there is no end to all his toil. His eyes are never satisfied with riches, so that he never asks, ‘For whom am I toiling and depriving myself of pleasure?’ This also is vanity and a miserable business.
verses.comment: Solitude focused on material gain is empty. This hints at the value of community and self-giving love, foundational to both natural law and revealed faith.

verses.text: Two are better than one, because they have a good reward for their toil.
verses.comment: The value of companionship and mutual support subtly anticipates the Church as a community of believers bearing each other's burdens (Gal. 6:2).

verses.text: For if one of them falls, the other will lift up his companion. But woe to him who is alone when he falls and has no one to help him up.
verses.comment: This further emphasizes the importance of fellowship—in practical and spiritual terms, echoing the New Testament emphasis on unity and mutual care within the Body of Christ.

verses.text: Again, if two lie together, they keep warm, but how can one keep warm alone?
verses.comment: The need for support extends even to the basic necessities, applying the value of solidarity in both natural and spiritual life.

verses.text: And if someone should overpower one, two can withstand him. A threefold cord is not quickly broken.
verses.comment: Strength lies in unity. The 'threefold cord' has been interpreted spiritually as an analogy for the relational nature of God’s people, and even Trinitarian notions. The importance of deep bonds and higher unity is suggested.

verses.text: Better is a poor and wise youth than an old and foolish king who will no longer be admonished.
verses.comment: Wisdom and humility are valued above status or age. This aligns with Christ’s teaching about childlike humility and receptiveness to guidance (Matt. 18:3-4).

verses.text: For he went out from prison to reign, even though in his own kingdom he was born poor.
verses.comment: Rising from poverty to rule connects to biblical stories of Joseph and even Christ’s humble beginnings, symbolizing divine exaltation of the lowly (Luke 1:52).

verses.text: I saw all the people living under the sun follow the youth who replaced the king.
verses.comment: Populace turning to the wise youth signifies the recognition of virtue over position—a theme that finds fulfillment in Christ, whom many followed in hope.

verses.text: There was no end to all the people, to all who were before them. Yet those who come later will not rejoice in him. Surely this also is vanity and chasing after wind.
verses.comment: Even great achievements fade with time—a call to seek lasting treasure in spiritual realities and communion with God (Matt. 6:19-21).
